text:
Copper Dog Whisky Solo Artist of the Year: Stormzy

Presented by Jeremy Corbyn

© Daniel Sannwald

Our first winner is an artist who has single-handedly ushered in a new age for grime music. Under his own label, #Merky, he’s proved he doesn’t need to sign to a major to top the charts, as he did with his debut album Gang Signs & Prayer, grime’s first No1 album. Not only can he rap and sing, he’s remained one of London’s most inspiring young men, encouraging his listeners to vote, pray and speak openly about mental health.

Read more: Watch Jared Leto sabotage GQ's Facebook Live stream at our Men Of The Year Awards

Editor's Special Award: Stranger Things

Presented by Natalie Dormer

© Netflix

Last summer, something extraordinary happened. A group of completely unknown teenagers cycled onto our Netflix accounts in one of the best TV shows of the year. Within weeks, they were no longer kids, but world-famous actors, and we were talking about The Upside Down and asking, “Where’s Barb?” Within months, those kids were award-winning too.The well deserved winners of the GQ Editor’s Special Award are the boys of Stranger Things, Caleb McLaughlin, Finn Wolfhard, Gaten Matarazzo and Noah Schnapp!

Creative Maverick of the Year: Sergei Polunin

Presented by Erin O'Connor

© Doug Inglish

This winner has never done things by the book. One of the most gifted ballerinas of his generation, he quit the Royal Ballet just two years after becoming the youngest principal dancer in its history, going on not only to star in a David LaChapelle video set to Hozier’s “Take Me To The Church”, which has been viewed more than 20 million times, but parlayed that into a film career that will see him star in Kenneth Brannagh’s Murder On The Orient Express later this year. He’s known as the “bad boy of ballet”, but he looks pretty good to us.

Special Achievement of the Year: Antonio Conte

Presented by Gordon Ramsey

© Claudio Porcarelli

There could only be one contender. Not only did our winner take the Premier League title at the first time of asking – something not done since José Mourinho first took over at Chelsea over a decade before. But it wasn’t just the result – it was the manner of the win, setting a new Premier League record for most wins in a single season and becoming the first man in history to win three Manager Of The Month awards in a row. Now, he has yet another.

Breakthrough Designer of the Year: Grace Wales Bonner

Presented by Jaden Smith

© Piczo

Not only did our next winner receive one of the most prestigious awards a young designer can receive, the 2016 LVMH Prize, she was assessed by one the most formidable judging panels: featuring Karl Lagerfeld, Marc Jacobs, Riccardo Tisci and JW Anderson, which says it all. This is a designer who, through her half-British, half-Jamaican upbringing, has translated London’s wonderful cultural melting pot into fashion.

Garage Act of the Year: Kurupt FM

Presented by David Walliams

© Hamish Brown

You may know them from the momentous and in no way fictional BBC Three documentary series People Just Do Nothing that has charted their remarkable rise. You probably know them as the garage superstars that are MC Grindah, DJ Beats, Steves and their manager Chabuddy G. And while some fools will tell you it’s a genius comedy that just won a BAFTA, GQ is having none of it.

Designer of the Year: Christopher Bailey

Presented by Skepta

© Steve Schofield

The winner of our next award is picking up Designer Of The year, but he could just as easily have been picking up Innovator, or Entrepreneur, or maybe even Special Achievement. As the Chief Creative Officer of Burberry, he has been the driving force behind a succession of firsts – from being the first label to stream catwalk shows, to being the first to merge men’s and women’s collections, to pioneering an initiative that lets customers buy clothes they see on the catwalk later that day. Oh, and he did all this while ensuring Burberry remained the premier luxury label in the world.

Band of the Year: Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds

Presented by Courtney Love

© Tom Oldham

After 34 years in the business, in which they’ve produced 16 albums and won nine awards, their sound has constantly evolved. Last year’s album, "Skeleton Tree", became their highest-charting album ever in the US and a No2 in the UK. This year's new compilation album, "Lovely Creatures", proves once again that they are, and always have been, in a league of their own.

Breakthrough Actor of the Year: James Norton

Presented by Tuppence Middleton

© Charlie Gray

In the past year, this winner has starred in not one, not two, but three hit TV shows, each one a conversation for the water cooler: as a heartthrob vicar in Grantchester, as a heartthrob prince in War & Peace, and a heartthrob psychopath in Happy Valley. We see a theme here… the man has good cheekbones. Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome on stage GQ's Breakthrough Actor Of The Year, James Norton!

Hugo Boss Most Stylish Man: Zayn Malik

© Doug Inglish

Some might say that going solo after years safely cocooned as a member of one of the world’s most famous bands would be a risky move. Not for this man. His phenomenal first album, Mind Of Mine, hit No1 on both sides of the Atlantic, and with his debut single, “Pillowtalk”, became only the third ever Brit to kick-start their solo career at the top of the American charts. But it’s not just music – with a sense of style that is both effortless and idiosyncratic, it’s our Hugo Boss Most Stylish Man, Zayn Malik.

Legend of the Year: Sir Geoff Hurst

Presented by GQ Editor Dylan Jones

© Jason Alden

During his 13 years as a striker for West Ham United, he played more than 400 times and scored 242 goals, winning both the FA Cup and European Cup Winners’ Cup. But it was one game and three goals – wearing the Three Lions of England – that ensured him sporting immortality. He remains the only player ever to score a hat-trick in a World Cup final.

Hugo Boss Woman of the Year: Adwoa Aboah

Presented by Poppy Delevingne

© Mariano Vivanco

Our next winner is less Woman Of The Year and more Woman Of A Generation. Not only has she fronted campaigns for the likes of Miu Miu and Calvin Klein, nabbed her first Vogue cover, and even appeared alongside Scarlett Johansson in Ghost In The Shell, she’s inspired young women with her willingnesss to discuss mental health. In July, the 25-year-old created Gurls Talk: an online platform to empower young women with a safe, supportive community.

Television Actor of the Year: Cillian Murphy

Presented by Jamie Dornan

© John Balsom

Cillian has had a blinder of a year. He hit the big screen all-guns-blazing in Free Fire, won hearts and minds as the shell-shocked soldier in Christopher Nolan’s magnificent Dunkirk and, this autumn, he returns in a role that he has made his own – as everyone’s favourite Brummy bad-man, Tommy Shelby, in the fourth series of one of the most deliciously British dramas ever made, Peaky Blinders. No wonder it counts the likes of Tom Cruise and Brad Pitt as super fans.

TV Personalities of the Year: The Grand Tour

Presented by Sir Ben Ainslie

© Gavin Bond

Some say our next winners pulled one of the greatest coups in television history. Some say they’re a cultural phenomenon. And some say they just like messing about in cars. All we know is, they’re brilliant, and the reason to plug that little Amazon box into your TV. The first episode of The Grand Tour became Amazon Prime’s most-watched series premiere in the world, and with a second series out later this year, they certainly have a reason to toot their own horn.

Maddox Gallery Artist of the Year: Wolfgang Tillmans

Presented by Winnie Harlow

© Karl Kolbitz

Wolfgang Tillmans is a German artist who began his career taking casual snapshots of his friends in 1991. In 2000, he became the first photographer, and first non-British artist, to be awarded the Tate’s coveted annual Turner Prize and, this year, he bagged his first major solo show at Tate Modern. And no wonder: his art has been instrumental to understanding our socio-political climate. His distinctive poster campaign against Brexit displayed a solidarity that surpasses nationality. Unlike many of his contemporaries, he proves art doesn’t just observe and comment, it has agency.

Comedians of the Year: Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon

Presented by Jourdan Dunn

© Charlie Gray

This award goes to not one, but two of the funniest men in the country. And not only do they have talent, they also have the sweetest gig on TV – touring the north of England, then Italy, then Spain, eating the finest food, drinking the finest wine and doing the finest impressions of Michael Caine. They have turned bickering into an art-form and melancholy into a punchline. They are GQ’s Comedians Of The Year – the brilliant stars of The Trip, Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon!

Rock 'n' Roll Star of the Year: Liam Gallagher

Presented by John Cooper Clarke

© Gavin Bond

Only 12 months ago, our next winner was ready to throw in the tambourine. But then he picked up his guitar, and within one year dropped a single, an album, a tour and, most importantly, landed a GQ cover. If that wasn’t enough to warrant an award, in the wake of the Manchester bombing, he gave a cathartic, beautifully unifying performance to a city, and a nation, in need of it.

Sportsman of the Year: Anthony Joshua

Presented by Idris Elba

© Matthew Brookes

If you didn’t witness our next winner in May as he heroically defeated Wladimir Klitschko in front of 90,000 fans at Wembley then, frankly, where were you? Knocked down and off his feet by round six, our next winner fought back in a way rarely seen outside of Rocky films, cementing his status not just as the heavyweight champion of the world, but a national treasure in waiting.

Politician of the Year: Sadiq Khan

Presented by Tinie Tempah

Our next winner has had quite the year – just not in the way he’d have wished. Yet the award of Politician Of The Year is as much about one’s calm in a crisis, and leadership when leadership is needed most. Three terrorist attacks in three months, the Grenfell fire and countless lives lost – but tonight’s recipient did not flag or waiver, he spoke of vigilance but not revolt, and he put his trust in the resolve of Londoners, who in turn put their trust in him.

Actor of the Year: Jared Leto

Presented by Annabelle Wallis

© Gavin Bond

Our next winner is an actor of outstanding ability. He is as at home playing the Joker in a lavish blockbuster like Suicide Squad as he is playing an Aids sufferer in the moving Dallas Buyers Club. He is an Oscar-winner, a musician, frontman of a band and a style icon. This year sees him giving another extraordinary display in the hotly anticipated Blade Runner sequel, Blade Runner 2049, and he is GQ’s Actor of the Year."

Inspiration of the Year: Pelé

Presented by Gareth Southgate

© Mauricio Nahas

It has been said that beauty is not the goal of competitive sports, but high-level sports are a prime venue for the expression of human beauty. That could barely be more true of our next winner. He is not responsible for football as we know it, but he is responsible for the highest ideals of it – it is he who is responsible for the notion of football as the beautiful game, to take a game and elevate it to an art-form. He is many of the awards you have heard given tonight all wrapped into one. He is a global Icon. He is a Legend. His Special Achievements include three World Cups. He is Edson Arantes do Nascimento. But you will know him, simply, as Pelé.

Icon of the Year: Mark Hamill

Presented by Simon Pegg

© Gavin Bond

Our final winner collects the Icon award. It’s an award that only goes to someone who has left an everlasting dent in the culture – and our next winner left a meteor crater. He is one of the best-loved action heroes of all time. He is the star of the biggest movie franchise in history. And this year, he is back – the last of his kind, in a galaxy far, far away... They don’t make heroes like this any more...
